Argh, love it or hate it. How do you even review this game when it becomes a new game whenever the new game releases. The new MW reboot series is ok, not as over the top as the classic ones. However, MW3 dropped the ball and became a war zone clone with no effort taken into it. Storyline is half interesting and characters are half developed and killed off insignificantly. However, this game is for the multiplayer. It's the only fast-paced twitch shooter you're gonna get. Gun play is smooth like a typical COD game but it certainly gets boring after a while even BO. There's nothing interesting about COD anymore. I was always a Battlefield multiplayer fan and will continue to be. 7/10.

Yo, I just queued into Call of Duty (Black Ops 6 edition), and it's like a therapy session where you respawn just to get teabagged by campers hiding in corners like they're auditioning for a horror flick‚Äîyour K/D lives forever, but your dignity gets a one-way ticket to the gulag! Omnimovement has me sliding into walls like a drunk penguin, popping heads with the new Ladra SMG while SBMM pairs me with sweats who treat every lobby like their last stand‚Äîhilarious rage fuel as I clutch 1v5 only for friendly fire to turn my squad into accidental war crimes.

Zombies? Round-based horde-fests in haunted maps like Boo-Town, where manglers explode your dreams mid-wave‚Äîpure dark comedy as you fist-bump undead before they nom your face off. Multiplayer's still popping with 90k-ish Steam peaks despite the drop-off (Blizzard's wallet thanks you), Season 6 Haunting events dropping slasher LTMs that had me cackling through gore. 8.5/10. Addictive hellhole‚Äîyour free time dies, but the headshots slap!

With 2019's [b]Modern Warfare[/b] I got drawn back into the [b]Call of Duty[/b] series, but all the good-will I felt about the series since then has slowly been eroded over the last few years.
Call of Duty and especially [b]Warzone[/b] have never been more player unfriendly, if not downright hostile.
Insane prices for store items of ever decreasing quality.
Low effort Battle passes you can only finish if you take up playing Call of Duty as your second job.
Constant upselling at every opportunity, even in your 70 Euros premium title.

This series is not worth the financial and time investment anymore.
At least not for me.

Call of Duty: Modern Warfare III: My 5000-Hour Diary of Being a Cheater Magnet in SBMM Hell üåü
(Rating: 10/10 for "one more game" addiction, 0/10 for Ricochet anti-cheat, ‚àû/10 for "EZ noob uninstall" therapy)
Day 1: Hype Train Derails (2023 Launch)
Drop $70 on "full game." Campaign? 5 hours of Warzone reskins‚Äîfeels like DLC for MW2. Multiplayer? Queue up, get matched with gods. Teammate 1: Octane wannabe slides off cliff. Teammate 2: Crypto drones himself. Me? P2020 spray-n-pray into a wall. Then cheater walls us with aimbot. "Welcome to MW3, paypig!"
Day 500: SBMM Says "Git Gud" (2024)
Hit Gold! Buy $20 bundle for that "meta" skin. Ranked? SBMM yeets me into Pred lobbies. Ping spikes to 200ms on Tokyo servers. Bullets? Ghost through enemies. Enemy: Cronus Zen kid with zero recoil beams me through smoke. Report? "Action taken" on my shadowban. Back to 150ms cheater lobbies.
Day 2000: Review Bomb Apocalypse (2025)
Grind battle pass for epic flatline blueprint. Activision: "Two passes/season, $20 each!" Steam goes Mostly Negative‚Äî"$70 DLC scam!" I uninstall... reinstall for Warzone integration. Cheaters? Banned 65k, but new ones spawn like zombies. Ricochet: "99% cheater-free!" Me: "In what universe?"
Day 3500: Cheater Chronicles Reloaded
Pred? Nah, Iridescent full of spinbots. Console "safe"? Cronus/XIM mag-dumps. PC? Wallhacks every 2/3 games. Watch death cam: Enemy snaps 180¬∞ through walls. Anti-cheat waves? Cheaters laugh, buy new accounts. I report 50, get "false positive" shadowban. Playing with bots now‚Äîliteral ones.
Day 5000: Operator Overload
Main Ghost‚ÄîOP! Nerf. Switch Soap‚Äîslide cancel queen! Nerf. Every gun: Buff week 1, trash week 2. Perks? Spam the meta 3. Spawns? Behind you, always. "Open Beta no SBMM" lied‚Äîfull release is sweat factory. Every legend balanced like my K/D: 0.8 forever.
Sound & Graphics: Boom... Then Crash (Until Packet Loss)
Gunshots? Crisp pew-pew. Explosions? Hollywood BOOM. Then smoke‚Äîwhite void hell. Footsteps? Hear from orbit, yours? Muted. Controller vibrates mid-clutch... disconnects. "FUUUUUUUUCK MY LOADOUT!" Neighbors: "SWAT or COD?"
Community: Toxic Family Reunion

Russian: "CYKA SLIDE BLYAT" (dies first).
Solo savior: "Ping rez" (ghosts).
Me: "Group?" ‚Üí Mute + "FEEDER NOOB."
Streamers: Hacked, DDOS'd. Pros: "Cheaters ruined ranked."

Optimization: Activision's Prank DLC
FPS: 300 firing range ‚Üí 40 in TDM. Ping: 20 solo ‚Üí 180 crossplay. Crashes: Mid-1v3 ace. Hitreg: Bullets teleport. "Server issues!" Every patch: 100GB download for "bug fixes" that add more bugs.
Conclusion: Why I Haven't Quit (Send Help)
MW3 isn't a game‚Äîit's a masochist simulator. Every loss: "Skill issue/SBMM/cheater?" Every win: God mode (rare). Spent $500 on bundles invisible in shadowban. Cheaters banned? Respawn tomorrow. But that one 20-kill game... pure crack.
Recommend if:

You love screaming at Cronus kids.
Training patience for 200ms peeks.
Broke but flex $1000 tracer packs.

Silver 4 Pro Tip:
"Teammate calls bot? 'At least I don't Cronus‚Äîyour aim's Ricochet-free!' Roasted."
10/10 uninstalled... 5 mins later: "Queuing TDM."

I tried to come back to warzone and BO6 one last time before I leave the franchise forever but I simply cannot bring myself to play these games anymore. TLDR: Do yourself a favor. Delete the game. Play battlefield 6. Stop giving this greedy scummy company your money.

Oh man, where did we go so wrong...

I remember when a new Call of Duty felt like a separate game... something new and breathtaking. It wasn't always innovative, and sometimes formulaic. Why wouldn't it be? It worked, it was fun, and continued to take our attention away every fall season. Nowadays, a sense of "new" seems like a massive second thought. Activision is content on selling consumers a $70 dollar expansion pack every year, with minimal changes, and still have the audacity to charge every single season for Battle Passes and cosmetics. The last time I enjoyed a Call of Duty year round, and still play it often, was Modern Warfare (2019). That was the final time in my memory that I sat down with a Call of Duty, taken aback by the improvements. I could feel the love put into the game from the developers. That game felt like a love letter, not only to the fans, but to Call of Duty itself. Since then, they have done nothing but destroy the core values, and what made Call of Duty special. Do not buy Black Ops 7. It will only do irreparable damage to what you loved about Call of Duty and it's previous sub-franchises. 

We need a new IP. No one needed Black Ops 7 following Black Ops 6.

[h1] Resurgence is a great time but over 100 gb??? [/h1]
[b] Quick note that I have only played Warzone and the modes that come with it so this review is based solely on that experience [/b]
Call of Duty Warzone is a very clean shooter experience with a couple glaring issues making it hard to enjoy. Movement is not very responsive and feels awkward to control. Shooting feels amazing and is probably the best part about the experience, it's clean, precise and gunfights are fast and satisfying. There are two modes I played extensively enough to review and that is Battle Royale and Resurgence. I would give BR a 5/10 because the map design is not very good and the map in general is way too big for the kind of game this is. I said before that gunfights are quick and because of that the huge map feels empty very quickly, when you do find someone, the outcome of the fight is decided usually under 10 seconds so it feels like a lot of walking and looting for what ends up being a mediocre end. Resurgence on the other hand I would give a 7/10 and is a much better experience overall. Where BR falls short because of the fast gunfights, resurgence embraces it as the main gameplay mechanic, where you respawn over and over until your team is wiped. This suits the tight, precise shooting style of the game and is actually a really fun experience I would recommend.
Aesthetically the game is extremely dark and gray, while this suits the setting of the game it does end up being exceptionally boring. Collabs attempt to spice things up, but weird choices like American Dad and Chucky feel so out of place and ugly in the otherwise tactical art direction.
Overall Call of Duty isn't bad but based on my experience it can be very unsatisfying. Movement is limited and there is a lack of anything unique to make games stand out from each other, there aren't any moments where something particularly surprising or new happens because it is just the most bare shooter possible. Although it feels really clean and Resurgence is admittedly addicting, you can get that experience in a different Free-to-play game and the file size being over 100gb even at the minimum makes it extremely hard to justify keeping this in your library.

The moment I got mowed down by Stan Smith with a golden AK47, and then got called the N-word by a 12 year old running around as Beavis with a knife and screaming about my mom's t*ts? That was when I decided I'd had enough COD in my life and uninstalled the game permanently.

I'm 35 years old and have played COD since the original COD set in WW2 was released in 2003. I've played every single one of their games since and for a spell in my 20s streamed it regularly through Twitch.
I am one of the original players who helped make COD into the global RTS juggernaut it is today, and my verdict has changed from one of the greatest games of all time. Now my verdict is this:

The game is sloppy, messy, awkward and catering to zoomers with ADHD medication on hold at their local pharmacy. The game has turned itself from an amazing, immersive game, into a pathetic, self-deprecating joke, taking whatever obnoxious collabs they can manage to secure no matter how invasive or fundamentally idiotic it is. It decided to live by the saying 'If you can't beat them? Join them!' and leaned fully into its most destructive playerbase since the original CODMW2 multiplayer in 2009: The memers, the trolls and the obnoxious children with chronic keyboardwarrioritis. You'll know the people I'm talking about. You can recognize them when they write in the comments below, accusing me of writing this with AI. Lol. Those same children playing at 8-11 years old in 2009 are now older, and have their own credit cards to influence the game's direction with; and it showed the moment Roger from Family Guy called an airstrike on me.

The game is visually beautiful, but that's where the quality ends and the self-destructive indifference begins. No developer is as unapologetically signed out of giving a flying ****, as Activision is.
They have huge cash cows like Blizzard Entertainment under their belt. They have grown so large and so wealthy that they honestly don't care if the game's dogwater anymore. They release games in piss-poor states, with offensively bad progression strategies, and directionless, immersion destroying half-a**ed indifference to the games' quality.
They release hot garbage, cause they KNOW people will play their hot garbage, and look what that has caused. It has destroyed COD as a game, and now it can't even take itself seriously enough to reinvent itself in an admirable, relatable direction; No, instead they give you confetti deaths, guns with waifu skins on them, bright pastel colored clown outfits and awkward, cartoon-visualized jarring skins that have absolutely zero place in the game as a whole.

The games were getting bad before, but they're downright disgusting now.

Guess I'm going back to Battlefield. It's been a fun run, COD, but you're little more than a Meme simulator with poorly designed freedom spitters now.

Do NOT pre-order Black Ops 7 like I did. Don't make the same mistake as me.

I don‚Äôt even know where to start. This game is a masterclass in how to take a legendary franchise and run it straight into the ground. The servers are laggy half the time, the hit detection feels like it was coded during someone‚Äôs lunch break, and the skill-based matchmaking makes every lobby feel like a pro tournament.

The graphics may look good, but that‚Äôs about the only thing this game has going for it. The gameplay is stale, the maps feel recycled, and the constant microtransactions are a slap in the face. It‚Äôs less about skill now and more about who spent the most money on fancy skins and overpowered guns. This game is an overpriced mess that somehow gets worse with every update.

0/5 ‚Äî The only thing it kills is your patience.

This is completely biased toward Sony fanboys and ultimately they lose mass appeal. This write up is my personal opinion and is in no way endorsed or used to promote certain brands. There is a certain satisfaction in having a competitive edge that lead to eminent victories but the legend of Bagger Vance would persuade you otherwise that on the 18th hole you hit a birdie and not an eagle because the ball moved. It appears that today that is almost always going to be the truth if you own a DualShock 4 or later controller because of open source software like DS4Windows. My gripe in tolerating developer errors and the occasional game crash is imperative to winning and I mean winning a lot, like every exhibition if the opportunity presents itself.

Today this is possible thanks to what gamers call "soft aim assist" or aimbot. Now as far as I can remember creating rapid-fire was product of bypassing the circuit that led to your RT or RB with a switch or jumping the wires together. Today we have programs like the aforementioned that make the use of a controller with paddles obsolete. Specifically in games that have the ability to jump, the use of a paddle could make it so that you could control the joystick and the jump button without having to move your thumb and instead press one of the reprogrammed paddle buttons on a pricy aftermarket controller.

I've never purchased a DualShock controller because I've always played on Xbox and if you know those controllers you wouldn't want to buy a Sony. But today you have to because of programs that allow you to enhance the already buffed aim assist and if you are able to afford the one with more buttons hypothetically you are no longer playing a game that requires precision and skill but rather a contest and with any contest the loser is almost always the one that is not enhancing their performance. Personally you could defeat an unskilled opponent that relies on your lack of awareness.

What are your thoughts on defaulting to Sony engineered controllers, even in competitive settings? Whilst the other options are not readily detected in interfaces like DualShock windows. Sometimes its just fun to play the game but what happens when you become good, do you have the ability to just turn off the assists or are you just going to be mediocre and not nearly as amazing when you do use the DualShock functionality either way.

Well there's a lot wrong with this game but there was the minimum expected COD "FUN" ... if you can call it fun anyway! but it did NOT worth it. I decided to give BO6 & Treyarc studio a chance but COD was ruined for me even more.
* SBMM kills your vibe to play the game after a few good matches,
* Internet connectivity was AWFUL most of the time (In this day and age?????),
* Only game modes for weapon camo grind were half decent + Nuketown and even they just make you brain rot after a few matches,
* Unlocking stuff from armory requires you to literally give up your life to play with the guns you like but weren't there to get it at first(each gun requires 250,000 xp to unlock!),
* there were black cell, premium and normal battle passes in addition to event passes that cost even more extra money (of course there are bundles as well, each of them costing you about 20 USD and the game it self is 70 USD MINIMUM),
* There was always this obligation to  play with every meta instead of actually playing the game for fun & creativity with your own costume load out otherwise you wouldn't have fun,
* Don't even expect to have a military shooter vibe set in 90's when you play this game,
* story was MID and ending was WEAK, it was just gassed by the same people who have brought COD to this point,
* Devs will probably certainly forget about this game a couple of months after release of BO7, (and this is just a side note from me , BO7 LOOKS and even SOUNDS EXACTLY THE SAAAAAAME! Just with a coat of futuristic paint on it).
* You still have hackers and with life support ending for BO6, it's just gonna get worse cause devs won't even care,
* Game crashes for considerable amount of times,

AND A LOT MORE WHICH I JUST DON'T WANT TO TALK ABOUT THEM

So all in all, I gave one last chance to the IP and the studio that hooked my up in COD and made me love this franchise but was let down so bad that I don't wanna get near this game as far as I can see.
Imagine playing COD instead of BF6.

After playing Call of Duty: Warzone for about 40 hours, I can honestly say I‚Äôm hooked. The game is fast, intense, and super satisfying once you get into the rhythm. The gunplay feels really smooth, and every match has that adrenaline rush ‚Äî especially in those last few circles when it‚Äôs down to just a few squads.

I‚Äôve really come to appreciate how the loadout system works. Being able to customize my weapons to fit my playstyle makes a big difference, and getting my loadout mid-match always feels like a power-up moment. The map is huge and full of action, with tons of different places to drop depending on how aggressive or strategic I want to play.

Even after 40 hours, the game still feels fresh. No two matches ever play out the same way ‚Äî sometimes it‚Äôs chaos right from the start, other times it‚Äôs a slow build-up to an epic final fight. Playing with friends makes it even better; coordinating attacks and trying to pull off a clutch win is just pure fun.

Overall, Warzone has been a great experience for me so far. It‚Äôs got that perfect mix of skill, teamwork, and luck that keeps me saying, ‚ÄúJust one more match.‚Äù

According to the Bo6 approach, for example, if a mobile phone manufacturer launches a phone and consumers propose new terms after purchasing it, they must purchase other hardware before they can use it. If they do not purchase it, they cannot use it. Like Bo6, new terms are introduced after purchase. One is that new hardware needs to be purchased, and if an old TPM2.0 computer needs to be replaced, a new computer configuration also needs to be purchased. Both require consumers to spend extra money to use it, completely depriving consumers of their right to know and choose. Without informing consumers before purchasing the product, suddenly changing the terms results in consumers being unable to use the product and not allowing them to choose whether to refund. From any perspective, this is trampling on consumer rights and deceiving consumers

Call of Duty: Black Ops 6 is exactly what longtime fans of the franchise have been waiting for. From the moment you jump in, it's clear Treyarch and Raven Software listened to community feedback and pushed the envelope in all the right ways.

The campaign is back in full force and absolutely nails the tone ‚Äî gritty, cinematic, and full of twists. It feels like classic Black Ops storytelling, but sharper and more refined. The voice acting and set pieces are top-tier, and the pacing keeps you hooked from start to finish.

Multiplayer is where BO6 really shines. The maps are tight and well-designed, striking a perfect balance between fast-paced action and strategic depth. Gunplay feels smooth and satisfying, and the new movement system strikes a perfect middle ground between realism and fun. Weapon balancing is on point (so far), and progression feels rewarding without being grindy.

Zombies mode is a standout this time around ‚Äî atmospheric, challenging, and packed with lore. Whether you're a solo player or teaming up with friends, there's a ton of replayability here.

BO6 doesn't try to reinvent the wheel ‚Äî it just perfects it. With its polished gameplay, engaging content, and strong post-launch roadmap, this might just be the best Black Ops entry since BO2. If you're a CoD veteran or even just a casual FPS fan, Black Ops 6 is a must-play.

Call of Duty has officially turned into the fast-food of gaming ‚Äî same greasy menu every year with a slightly different wrapper. What‚Äôs the point of grinding camos and attachments when they‚Äôll just release Call of Duty: Slightly Different Grass Edition next fall? MW2019 started this yearly scam cycle and it ain‚Äôt stopping. BO3 was the last time CoD actually hit ‚Äî fun Zombies, solid multiplayer, and you didn‚Äôt have to fight a damn gingerbread man with an AR. Now it‚Äôs all copy-paste nonsense and ‚Äúnew features‚Äù nobody asked for, like that human shield move that gets used maybe once a century. Treyarch and Activision out here speedrunning how fast they can milk nostalgia and call it ‚Äúinnovation.‚Äù I don‚Äôt want Beavis, Butthead, or SpongeBob in a warzone ‚Äî I want gritty, battle-scarred soldiers, not cartoon mascots on the frontlines. If I get killed by one more holiday cookie with an M4 I‚Äôm uninstalling mid-rage. 1/10, only points go to the uninstall button actually working.

Call of Duty: A Monument to Greed and Laziness

This is not a game. It is a meticulously engineered cash machine dressed up as entertainment. Every year, the same recycled maps, the same weapons, and the same ‚Äúnew‚Äù modes get repackaged like it is some kind of innovation. It is obvious the developers could not be bothered to make anything truly fresh because why risk creativity when they can just squeeze the fanbase dry?

Microtransactions are shoved in your face everywhere. Want the full experience? That will cost extra. Cosmetics, battle passes, loot boxes, basically everything that could have been fun is locked behind a paywall or a grind designed to frustrate. The multiplayer is a chaotic mess that rewards pay-to-win behavior more than skill, and the matchmaking is broken, unbalanced, and seems designed to frustrate you into spending money on XP boosts.

Campaigns are equally insulting. They are hollow, cinematic fluff with all the depth of a puddle. The stories are recycled nonsense, the characters forgettable, and the gameplay feels like an afterthought. It is obvious these were designed to look good in trailers rather than provide a meaningful experience.

Graphically, it is a soup of mediocrity disguised with filters. Every feature screams ‚Äúsafe,‚Äù every mechanic screams ‚Äúlazy.‚Äù There is no love, no care, just the cold, calculated greed of a corporation that knows its audience will open their wallets regardless of quality.

Call of Duty is not a game anymore. It is a product designed to make money, and anyone looking for actual fun is being actively exploited. Avoid it unless you enjoy being insulted while handing over your cash.

[h1] A complete waste of time, money and storage space. [/h1]

My original review for this game, back when it was only Modern Warfare II, was going to be quite lengthy and in-depth. When Modern Warfare III released my review became egregiously long, even if my points were summarized concisely. Since then, Call of Duty Black Ops 6 and Call of Duty Black Ops 7 have been released. This entry in the Steam store, this "game", is actually where you can purchase all of the aforementioned games and download Warzone for free. I have not actually played Black Ops 6 or 7 as I gave up on Call of Duty before those games launched. That makes this review somewhat pointless as now Modern Warfare II and III now have their own Steam store entries where one could purchase and review them individually, however I cannot do so because despite purchasing both games from this Steam entry, I did not purchase them after they were made available individually from the Steam store. Fantastic.

Even if I had played all 4 games, a thorough review of them would still be pointless in my opinion. No matter how thorough, it would ultimately be repeating points that have already been made to death and recounted in countless videos, articles, and other reviews. Furthermore, this isn't a case where there is some decency left that warrants at least some consideration over purchasing one of these games. Even if you justify some positive aspect, it is buried by numerous negative ones. I don't even know if the gameplay is good or feels good anymore. [b] In short, there is no point to any of these games. Both individually and collectively, they are all a waste of time. [/b] MWII was heavily flawed but had its moments, everything after is just terrible and replete with issues like awful UI, virtually no player socialization, original map design that is average at best, constant updates and shader compilations, to name a few. The ingame store is clearly the highest priority, and the game is constantly pushing the player to spend real money on CoD points to purchase items on top of marketing a seasonal battlepass. Said items are almost all gaudy cosmetics that completely ruin the game's identity. Are you purchasing a game? Or are you purchasing a store that has a half-assed game attached to it? Server issues and bugs are abound and there have been instances where players (including myself) have lost much of their earned progress, if not all of it. The singleplayer story isn't particularly good, the multiplayer is bland, zombies is silly in a very not-fun way and everything else in between is just pointless. Remember DMZ? What is the point of complimenting the graphical and audio fidelity of these games if its behind countless amounts of shaders that take a sometimes egregious amount of time to compile even on an excellent PC. Some of the ingame assests are AI generated, including some of the items available for purchase for real money in the ingame store! What do all of these devs actually work on? If they're willing to incorporate AI even to this "smaller" degree what's stopping them from using it for more content in the future or even future titles? Why should anyone "support the devs" by paying real money for any of it? The Warzone map is awful and with the new mechanics it is a bore to play at best and downright miserable at worst. It is nowhere close to the fun and intense experience of Warzone 1 on Verdansk. There are even more issues and even some missing features from previous titles, I am just scratching the surface. [b] I haven't even mentioned that all of the games combined are somewhere in the ballpark of 500gb [/b] last I checked. [b] The Warzone launcher alone is 160gb. [/b]

[b] If you loved Modern Warfare 2019 and/or Warzone 1 on Verdansk like I did, these games are not worth your time, money or storage space. There is nothing for you, for us, here. [/b] There is more, but I think I've made my point and presented the same conclusion that many have already arrived at. Call of Duty isn't dead, but it's husk, lacking in identity and real substance is a shameful amalgamation of the worst trends in AAA gaming implemented in the worst ways. Death, dignified or otherwise, would be a release for Call of Duty.

As someone who has been a huge CoD enjoyer and is someone who loves the older games I do have to say, while Black Ops 6 may feel like its overrated and there's nothing actually new and it definitely has a very large janky side to it that just makes the game feel way to skill based and not enough actual fun game play I do have to mention that a lot of the problem isn't so much that CoD is the problem more the fact there a significantly HIGHER amount of HACKERS and CRONUS users in the game that end up ruining the experience. Warzone is a good example of this and is why I no longer have a love for Warzone BECAUSE of the excessive number of HACKERS! I do want to give credit to CoD for trying to make the game fun and with recent news of possibly getting an actually functional anti-cheat in the game it does give me a slight bit of hope for the upcoming updates. I can not say if you should pay the money to play Black Ops 6 but if you are a fan and aren't looking to BE THE BEST or take the game play too seriously then this wouldnt be a bad game to put some time into. I do however have to agree that Black Ops 7 is definitely not worth picking up, from watching a lot of streams and videos on the game it doesnt look like something Id recommend playing BECAUSE there is literally no game and literally nothing actually fun looking even from the launch trailer. ALSO WE DONT NEED A NEW COD WHEN BLACK OPS 6 HAS BARELY BEEN OUT THAT LONG!!!! While I am recommending yes it is NOT my actual opinion I am merely choosing it to post this review....As I stated I cant say that you should or shouldnt buy this game but more that you should go off what your opinion and game style says.

I‚Äôve played almost every CoD since MW2, and honestly, Black Ops 6 is the first one in years that actually feels fresh. The campaign hooked me right away ‚Äî it‚Äôs got that classic Treyarch intensity but with way more freedom. You can sneak, go loud, or mix both, and it never feels repetitive. The story‚Äôs tight, the pacing‚Äôs good, and it keeps you guessing all the way through.

Multiplayer‚Äôs where the game really shines. The new omnidirectional movement system changes everything ‚Äî you can dive, strafe, and fight with way more control than before. Gunplay feels crisp, the maps are well-designed, and for once, time-to-kill feels balanced. It rewards skill but still lets casuals have fun.

Zombies is a huge win too. It feels like old-school survival but bigger ‚Äî more to explore, more to do, and the atmosphere is top-tier. You can tell Treyarch put love back into it.

There are still minor gripes ‚Äî a few skins are too flashy, and some missions drag ‚Äî but overall, Black Ops 6 nails that mix of nostalgia and innovation. It‚Äôs fast, fun, and finally gives CoD fans something to get excited about again.

I had high hopes for Call of Duty: Black Ops 6, and while I enjoyed my time with it, this game feels like a shadow of what Black Ops 1 once was. The campaign is flat, the maps are lazy reskins at best, and the zombie mode has lost the spark that once set it apart.

On top of that, the constant stream of cosmetic crossovers, from rollercoaster gun skins to Ninja Turtles, only highlights how far the series has drifted from its roots. Call of Duty: Black Ops 6 is polished but hollow, a reminder that when creativity takes a back seat to monetization, even iconic franchises can lose their identity.

Review for Black Ops 6 after free week

I liked the single player campaign story , nice puzzles and the zombies actually fit the plot.
In multiplayer the game was similar to BO2 , the smg is king only rat snipers can get you :) In my opinion is very easy to get hip fire kills and grenade kills. The game has crossplay so it`s effortless to get a high kd ratio. Prone players are difficult to detect but after a kill the enemy model disappears so you can`t mistake them with a dead enemy.
The game has a lot of graphics options, and you can cap your FPS for menus and  gameplay individually and can display fps and gpu info. 
The steam version of the game had a problem after an update, the signle player wasn`t working ,someone shared a workaround to roll back to a previous build for the SP and it worked :) The bug got fixed on the last free day because Activision doesn`t care about the PC players.
80 euro is just too much. I vote with my wallet , i won‚Äôt pay more than ‚Ç¨60 for any game, and for CoD my limit is $15.
Ignoring the price, I‚Äôd give BO6 a 7/10.

Call of Duty (2025) ‚Äî Same Game, Different Year

I‚Äôve played Call of Duty for years, but at this point‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs honestly a 1/10 experience. The series feels completely lifeless now.

1. Same Old Formula:
Every new release feels like a copy-paste of the last one. Same maps, same guns, same recycled animations ‚Äî just with a new name and $70 price tag.

2. Terrible Optimization:
Even high-end PCs struggle with performance. Constant crashes, texture bugs, frame drops ‚Äî it‚Äôs like the devs forgot to test it before release.

3. Pay-to-Win & Microtransactions:
You pay full price, then get bombarded with overpriced skins, bundles, and battle passes. Half the game feels locked behind a paywall.

4. Boring Campaign:
The single-player mode is short, predictable, and feels like an afterthought. It‚Äôs more like an extended tutorial for multiplayer than a real story.

5. Multiplayer Disaster:
Unbalanced weapons, hackers everywhere, skill-based matchmaking that makes every game sweaty ‚Äî it‚Äôs not fun anymore.

6. Massive File Size:
Why does the game take 200+ GB for a recycled experience? At this point, downloading Call of Duty feels like installing Windows twice.


---

 Final Verdict:
Call of Duty used to be the king of shooters ‚Äî now it‚Äôs just a cash-grab zombie franchise. No innovation, no care, no soul.

 Rating: 0.00001/10 ‚Äî Feels more like a store than a game.

Black Ops 6 is the pinnacle of disappointment and a masterclass in wasting your time. This "game" is quite frankly a storefront disguised as an FPS shooter to suck you in and make you spend your hard earned cash. Unless you have a couple close friends to play with routinely, and you don't mind getting melted by the sweatiest of sweats and cheaters, then avoid at all costs.

Let's start with zombies mode. It is a joyless treadmill where every gun has the same mind-melting grind. Want gold? Grind 2000 headshots. Want opal? Grind 30 special zombie kills. Want the final camo? Pray to the RNG gods while repeating the same waves over and over because apparently originality is now a crime. Want the camos on a different gun? Cool, do the exact same thing, over, and over, and over again. Solo play is a nightmare. Maps are either tiny, claustrophobic corridors or ‚Äúopen‚Äù areas that still manage to feel like a giant hamster cage. Every second is a repeat of the last. Sound effects? Same. Enemies? Same. Narration? Same. Goals? Same. Map? Same. Your brain doesn‚Äôt even get a chance to have an original thought.

Warzone isn‚Äôt any better. Verdansk is supposedly ‚Äúmassive‚Äù but is as dead as a boardroom meeting. No weather, no night cycle, no environmental variety, nothing to break up the monotony. You drop in, you shoot a few sweaty players, you die, and then you do it again. And again. Don‚Äôt even get me started on the cosmetics. Hundreds of overpriced skins and AI generated slop shoved down your throat while the game itself barely delivers. With thousands of developers working on this, you‚Äôd think they could churn out at least five maps that aren‚Äôt eye wateringly dull. Instead, we get a single ugly map over and over in a sea of yellow. Genius. Imagine if we had 5 maps for instance, downtown New York city, the streets of Paris, the Amazon rain forest, African desert, and the side streets of Japan, with weather, day and night cycles to match? You would think that a company with enough money to buy a small country and enough employees to fill a city they could accomplish something, anything at all. But no.

Graphics on a high end PC? Ha. Flat, bland, texture-less, lighting that looks like it came straight from 2013, all capped for last-gen consoles. Oh you spent $2000 building a gaming PC? Sorry, you get the same graphical quality as a $300 Xbox One, aside from a few extra frames that don't even matter because lag and latency is your biggest op. Menus are glacial. Want to check an operator? Prepare to stare at a loading icon for 20 seconds like a full grown adult playing solitaire in a cave while the game attempts to load in this insanely detailed, totally not computer generated AI skin. Every interaction outside of a match is painful, and insulting.

Black Ops 6 is repetitive, uninspired, and technically sloppy. It feels like the entire game was designed as a time-sinking storefront disguised as a shooter. With its only goal being to suck as much money out of you as possible, while cosplaying as an FPS shooter so you play at least 2 hours worth and can't return. This once highly coveted franchise has simply turned into a slightly more realistic Fortnite. Progression is meaningless, maps are boring, menus are slow and broken, and zombies is an endurance test that punishes anyone with a functioning brain. Play it if you want to watch hours of your life vanish while grinding cosmetic rewards nobody asked for. Otherwise, steer clear. This is not a game. This is a punishment.

Call of Duty HQ is not just user-hostile annoyance, the way it is implemented in Steam environment turns it into a complete abomination.  The most recent CoD game is in your library displayed just as "Call of Duty¬Æ" (same for the shortcut on your desktop etc.) instead of its actual full name. Once they release next game, "Call of Duty¬Æ" entity migrates to it. My playtime on this thing currently is a combination of playtime of BO6 and one of the older CoDs etc. - the confusion is breaking all the neat Steam stuff that works fine for every game other than CoD.

I completely avoid CoD MP - while I understand the appeal of a MP shooter with (some) of the silly skins, I believe it is a terrible idea to combine it into one MP game with what is meant to be maybe unrealistic but definitely realistic-looking military shooter.

I guess I should thank Activision for making BO6 campaign available for free in an attempt to compete with Battlefield 6 - and I would (thank them) if they did not ruin it in the middle of the free period with a needless patch that made the campaign almost impossible to launch and highly unstable.

A good chunk of BO6 campaign is actually more fun then I expected - despite the stunning, diverse, brave and inclusive bunch of characters and some cringe character-building, it mostly works as a decent sequel to Black Ops Cold War. There is one [spoiler]hallucination/zombie[/spoiler] level that some players might find out of place but other than that it works - except the last mission, crappy Ubisoft-style [spoiler]drug trip[/spoiler].

If the BO6 campaign was playable without CoDHQ and all the online hassle and bugs, it would be well worth 10-15 bucks depending on how much of a CoD fan a player is.  As I actually experienced it, it was so-so worth the time invested at 0 bucks cost.

I grew up with Call of Duty. I still remember playing CoD 2 on PS2, it was raw, fun, and unforgettable. Then came Modern Warfare (2007), and it blew the world away. MW2, MW3‚Ä¶ those games defined an era. They were about gameplay, story, and respect for the player.

Fast forward to today with Black Ops 6, and what do I get? A wall of BIOS errors, TPM checks, Secure Boot demands, forced online logins, and third‚Äëparty accounts, just to play the campaign. I don‚Äôt want to be a computer scientist to enjoy a single‚Äëplayer story. I don‚Äôt want to risk BIOS updates or troubleshoot firmware just to launch a game I paid for.

And it‚Äôs not just me. Another player summed it up perfectly:

Download the game

Download an update

Launch the game, it forces another update

Close, update, restart( sometimes repeat multiple times)

Try to play campaign, game closes and reopens

Campaign won‚Äôt start because of server issues

Game freezes, you relaunch, repeat‚Ä¶ nothing works and It‚Äôs the worst gaming experience I‚Äôve had in years.

This is not gaming. This is punishment for being a paying customer. 

Meanwhile, Activision is busy selling childish skins, battle passes, and flashy cosmetics. The franchise that once set the standard for shooters is now just a storefront with a game attached. The soul is gone.

Thank God I only tried the demo, it showed me everything I needed to know. I‚Äôd rather put my money where companies still value gamers. Honestly, even EA seems to have learned from their mistakes, Battlefield 6 looks like it actually respects players. Meanwhile, COD is a hollow shell.

I miss the days when games were made for gamers, not shareholders. I miss when you could just click on a game, play with your friends, laugh, and have fun, not fight BIOS settings, TPM firmware, endless updates, and server errors.

Until Activision wakes up, real gamers should boycott Call of Duty. Stop feeding this machine until they remember who made them great in the first place.

I also notice that my recommendation doesn't count towards the overall ranking of the game because it's a free game.

I'll say it one last time: This is the kind of game that explains why people play Overwatch 2 for the shooter content.

Okay, I know this seams insane, 245 hours, and not recommended? Well it's quite complicated, this game was so insanely addicting for the first few months, I got better, watched tips and tricks videos. I was addicted, waiting to get home so I can play COD Warzone, playing 3-10 hours a day with my friend. I couldn't stop, trying to find the weapons with the fastest time to kill, watching clickbait videos on TTK and broken weapons. I truely couldn't stop playing or thinking about it, flexing on friends, getting too happy when I get a clutch, just having a great time. Seams like I loved it, but why is it not recommended? Well, it sort of ruined my taste, making me not want to play games, but saying I will and just watching videos instead of gaming. Whenever my friends asked to play it, I said no, just not having any fun for almost 4 months, just watching videos or playing games I don't enjoy. I have now found games that I actually enjoy, having fun every time I get on my computer.

If you don't want to read this review, just know, you can't stop playing it for a while, and you burn out on it, having no fun online for weeks up to months. Although, you might experience it differently, but it is too damn fun for the first months. Have a great day!

Downloaded this because I wanted to try out Black Ops 6's campaign during the free trial period. I quite enjoyed the older Black Ops campaigns so I had hoped this would be a fun way to spend an afternoon at least. After a lengthy download, an annoying launcher to jump through and a long shader processing step I was finally ready to play. For my efforts I was greeted by constant game feel ruining stutters and weird graphical issues for the first couple missions before the game finally crashed on the third. I thought I'd restart my computer and come back to it the next day. Maybe things would be better.
The next day comes, I get to the BOps 6 campaign menu and I press the button to resume the mission I was on. Game starts loading... and never stops. Fifteen minutes later: still nothing but the black screen with the rotating orange icon in the bottom right corner. Try verifying game files and relaunching, it does nothing. See a suggestion that the game shaders might have broken themselves somehow. I look for the option to clear shaders, the menu search says its in there, but clicking on the setting from the search page brings no such setting. Another relaunch fixed this and made the option reappear. That part isn't the worst issue, just some poor interface design. I wouldn't even bring it up if it weren't for the fact that every launch requires dealing with the awful launcher which adds a couple minutes to every single launch attempt. After restarting the shader processing step again I leave the game for about an hour: 0% done. Thinking a restart might fix the issue I restart and let it run again. This time 2+ hours and still 0%. Its at this point that I decide that I'm done with this.
The only positive in this miserable excuse for a video game is that at least I didn't put any money into it. At least it served as a free lesson: teaching me never to put a single dime into this garbage. Shame on you Activision for offering a game in this state, and shame on you Microsoft for letting things get this bad.

The Call of Duty franchise has cemented itself as a true pioneer of the first-person shooter genre. From its early World War II roots to its futuristic twists and gritty modern warfare reboots, it has consistently delivered unforgettable campaigns, cinematic storytelling, and genre-defining mechanics. Whether you love it or love to complain about it, there‚Äôs no denying that Call of Duty has pushed the FPS space forward more than almost any other franchise.

One of the brightest jewels in its modern crown is Warzone Resurgence ‚Äî a masterclass in fast-paced, high-adrenaline gameplay. The fluidity of combat, constant re-engagement, and that addicting loop of "just one more drop" makes it one of the most replayable modes in battle royale history. It‚Äôs chaotic, it‚Äôs exhilarating, and it‚Äôs pure dopamine in digital form.

That said, no franchise is perfect ‚Äî and Skill-Based Matchmaking (SBMM) remains the series' most baffling decision. In public lobbies, SBMM simply doesn‚Äôt belong. If it's not ranked, then it shouldn‚Äôt play like ranked. Random matchmaking based solely on ping and connection quality should be the default. The idea of manipulating lobbies ‚Äî and even worse, skill-based hit registration ‚Äî is downright absurd in any mode. It punishes good players, suffocates casual players, and ultimately hurts the experience for everyone.

But here‚Äôs the thing: for the first time in a long time, I‚Äôm feeling genuine excitement for what‚Äôs next.

Black Ops 7 looks like the return to form we‚Äôve been begging for. The promise of SBMM changes, fresh movement mechanics, and ‚Äî most importantly ‚Äî a continuation of the legendary Black Ops 2 storyline has me all in. In fact, I‚Äôve already purchased the Vault Edition for the first time ever, which should tell you everything about my expectations.

Call of Duty isn‚Äôt just surviving ‚Äî it‚Äôs evolving. And if Black Ops 7 delivers on its promises, we might be entering a new golden era.

[h1]CALL OF DUTY: BLACK OPS 6 IS PURE CINEMA[/h1]

Okay, this game was amazing. First off all, this is the only Black Ops game I played after finishing the first 2 and this game had one of the best gameplay features from the previous games. The story was good, the twists in this game hit just like the ones in Black Ops 1 and 2. Of course, a game cannot simply just be perfection and in this game it‚Äôs the same with its flaws. Some missions were really good and meanwhile some were absolutely trash. In my opinion, High Rollers was the best mission in this game and Emergence was one of the worst in this game. The characters had so much detail and backstory presented in this game through interaction and dialogue choices. I really liked the gameplay in this game and its been really improved from Black Ops 1 and 2. The variety of weapons in this game also deserves a mention as they are really great. The ending is kinda mysterious because I have no idea of the person showed in the end of the cut-scene. That‚Äôs all honestly and I wish that Call of Duty will still bring out good, great and masterpiece story campaigns over the other games they make in the future, because this one was amazing. I really liked this game,

1. Got 130hrs just because of warzone. But then I realized how big of a problem aim assist is. Every game that I've played since I found out about aim assist seemed unfair. I did my best to track the enemy, but I ended up dying anyway, even though it took less effort from him than it took me.
2. Some of the skins are really good. However they don't fit CoD at all. Skins wouldn't be a problem if I was talking about fortnite but since its CoD skins are more than a problem here. Playing this game makes me feel like I'm about to throw up or as if I'm high.
3. FOR PEOPLE WHO CONSIDER BUYING BO 7:
I played bo7 open beta and the game feels the same as bo6. Play free access while you still can and then decide whether you wanna buy bo7 or not. But personally I'd recommend bf6.

I played during the free week because I love the CoD Zombies from WaW to BO4, I played every single one including infinite warfare zombies and Ghost Aliens. I liked BO3 so much that I learned the mod tools and made the Courage the Cowardly Dog map for it.

I figured I may as well try out the zombies mode on BO6 while its free. I did not like it. I played the first 3 maps, I did not get very far but it's nothing like the game I enjoyed. The UI is atrocious, the ads and the loading screens and getting the game to run in the first place took over an hour before I was able to even play. It does not look like zombies and it does not play like zombies. WaW through BO4 actually felt like Zombies. This is something else. I don't know how to describe it other than bad. Killing zombies and progressing rounds did not feel engaging, I was not enjoying any of it. The guns were bad, the zombies fell and shambled all over the place, the spider scorpion wannabe dogs were dumb. The wannabe parasites that are annoying to shoot. The weird health bars over all the zombies heads. None of it feels engaging, its a weird shell or skinwalker in zombies image. 

The maps are also uninspired and bad. It all looks the same and it all plays the same and none of it was memorable. Liberty falls was the worst one, just a random city with a random church in it. How is it that the remake of nuketown (BO4) has more character than liberty falls? The other map I played that I can't even remember the name of looked like a confusing mix of Call of the Dead + Mob of the dead + Five without anything redeeming either. I got on a boat for some reason and drove around but the zombies don't swim so you can just sit on the boat seemingly forever as long as you don't get out. I got out of the boat to shoot some of them just standing on the edge of the beach and then took damage and died. Very cool, what an interesting mechanic.

I'm glad I didn't buy this and I appreciate them giving it out for free to show the remaining few hundred people like me that they made the right choice in not purchasing it. My suggestion is to just never buy a new CoD game and play the old ones in local, they will hold up until the end of time. BO1 to BO3 will never not be fun to play once in a while.

Call of Duty: Warzone epitomizes excellence in modern competitive gaming, serving as a sophisticated amalgamation of strategic complexity, tactical precision, and emergent gameplay dynamics. The game‚Äôs high skill ceiling demands continuous cognitive engagement, with players required to synthesize information rapidly and adapt to an ever-shifting battlefield. Core innovations, such as the Gulag mechanic and the economy-based revival system, introduce multifaceted layers of resilience and resource management that transcend the conventional battle royale formula, offering a nuanced balance between risk and reward. The meticulously crafted game world‚Äîspanning diverse, intricately designed environments‚Äîprovides a rich canvas for players to execute sophisticated tactical maneuvers. Success is contingent not only on individual proficiency but on collective coordination, with communication and team dynamics playing a pivotal role in optimizing strategic outcomes. Moreover, the game‚Äôs constant evolution through seasonal updates, new mechanics, and balance adjustments ensures that it remains responsive to player feedback, perpetually revitalizing its competitive landscape. At its core, Warzone fosters a multifaceted, high-stakes environment where the confluence of strategic foresight, mechanical execution, and psychological tension cultivates an intensely immersive experience. Through its mastery of emergent playstyles, Warzone stands as a paradigmatic model of interactive design, offering a compelling and intellectually stimulating experience that continually engages both seasoned veterans and newcomers alike.

Well... I have some years to play a CoD game so when I saw the free play week for Black Ops 6 I thought to give the singleplayer a try.

So, I get back from work on Friday evening, I press play game and... ~151GB to download, estimated time 4 hours...
I think [i]"Ok, let's play something else while this downloads"[/i], two hours in I check, same as before, it turns out I had to check [i]Allow downloads during gameplay[/i] in steam settings... [i]"I guess I'll try it tomorrow..."[/i]
Saturday afternoon, I get back from the supermarket...
Driver update! (15 minutes pass) Restarting...
Windows Update! (another 15 minutes pass)
Finally, starting the game, and... Login screen! [i]"Why do I have to create an account in a game I got from Steam, where I'm already logged in to play the single player campaign?"[/i]
Anyway, I proceed to create an Activision account... mid-typing a popup informs me that I have no internet and the game need to be restarted. I check, internet works fine, no issues...
Restarting the game...
Repeating the account creation process... Please verify your e-mail!
I check the verification e-mail... it's not just verification, it's linking my Steam account to Activision without any mention of it in the game window. [i]"Well, let's proceed to linking..."[/i]
Restarting the game....
And... PHONE NUMBER REQUIRED

Uninstalling!

[h3]Why I need to provide you my phone number in order to try the [b]single player[/b] campaign?!?[/h3]

On the positive side,
I've learned that if I want to play a recent CoD game I have to give Activision access to my tax forms and my firstborn, but I learned it without having to spend 44 euros first, as that would have been worse.

Playing Warzone 2.0 has been an overall great experience the game's gunplay, graphics, sound design, and overall mechanics are genuinely impressive. The optimization is also quite good it runs smoothly on my device without any major FPS drops.

But the biggest issue is the cheaters.

In 7 to 8 out of every 10 matches, you'll encounter hackers (like wallhackers and aimbot users) or Cronus Zen users all of whom have a clear advantage over legitimate players. These players openly use cheats, and even after reporting them, Activision‚Äôs anti-cheat system takes no visible action.

This completely ruins the experience for honest players. In high-skill lobbies, competitive integrity feels almost non-existent.

The most disappointing part is that Activision doesn‚Äôt seem to take these problems seriously.

Tip: If you want to save some space, go download this game on Microsoft Store; there you can choose the option to download  just the Warzone mode steady of the whole game. But if you want to play and have fun, just forget about this game and go straight to Battlefield 6. You won`t regret it ;)

Call of Duty: Black Ops 6 became free temporarily this week because Battlefield 6 just launched as a desperate attempt of increasing its players. This did not work at all.

This is not a review about plot or gameplay. 

It seems that, in their frantic move of making the game free, the developers forgot the various abysmal issues of COD HQ. Or, perhaps they ignored them. My multiple attempts to start the game all appeared futile, due to the laughable anticheat service preventing the instance from starting. This, though, has not discourage me from trying yet again to play the campaign. I thus uninstalled and reinstalled the gigantic 180 gigabytes of resources (itself a result of the refusal of the developers to optimize or compress the unreasonably large texture packs). 

After reinstall I was finally able to launch the game, but yet again, I was not able to play the campaign. On startup, a window popped up and informed me the app required an update. I ignored the fact that I've just reinstalled, and clicked proceed. The page started to shift between two prompts: "accessing relay" and "downloading update". Then, unfortunately, an error popped up indicating failure. Clicking "restart update" was fruitless, so I terminated the process. My various struggles in vain had finally convinced me that I would never be able to solve the issue on my own, thus I consulted various videos on Youtube. The exorbitant amount of different tweaks to internet, bluetooth, drivers, settings and compatibility all proved ineffectual. Desperate, I decided to make one final try, and if the game still refuses to launch, I would uninstall.

To my surprise, the next time I launched, the issue miraculously solved itself. I am suddenly overwhelmed with excitement: perhaps I'll be able to play the campaign after all! 

Little did I suspect of the obstacles I would face next. 

After a compulsory account creation process, I was prompted to "connect phone number to Steam." Despite my unwillingness to do so I proceeded. Finally, the login process finished. Upon reaching main page, I am forced to click through 2 advertisements of their extremely dull-witted Battle Pass and skip through a video showcasing the multitude of gormless-but-colorful weapon skins. In the end, I reached the actual launch button.

I clicked, full of hope. 

"Accessing relay" appears yet again, with process stuck at 0%, shattering my final attempt.

In my rage, I uninstalled the game, and decided that, indeed, this was it.

As you can see, fellow new and old players who happen to stumble upon this review, the developers have truly abandoned this dreadful, unoptimized product. You can also see that my whole "35 minutes" of playtime registered on account is entirely dedicated to trying to get this calamity to start. It is impossible to imagine this as the developers' attempt to affect BF6 sales, yet here it is. To me, even a game with bad plot is acceptable sometimes. A game that refuses to launch, forces me to babysit it to even reach start page, then gets stuck again miserably is never acceptable. 

All in all, this is the epitome of Treyarch and Activison's atrocious code writing. Do not buy it. Do not play it. Even if it's free.

Call of Duty: Black Ops 6 Review

‚ÄúThe nature of our enemy is unclear now.‚Äù

Black Ops 6 is the game that has everything but delivers nothing. It has incredible gun play, smooth FPS movement, jaw dropping graphics, and talented voice actors and game developers. And yet, it has no soul, no humanity, and no worthwhile message to impart to the world. Call of Duty cannot help but indulge in its insecurities about America, telling its audience that ‚Äúthere are always enemies‚Äù to defeat, murder, kill, and pillage. In this entry, American guns go inward toward an internal spy conspiracy that feels generic and unsubstantial while washing its hands off any political context despite being set during the Gulf War. 

Let‚Äôs start with the positives. Black Ops 6 has truly refined gunplay that evokes an addictive quality. It‚Äôs no mystery that CoD has survived in the gaming landscape despite its consistent mediocrity. The gameplay is just that good and the people always want more. The new omnidirectional movement is a reinvigorating addition to the franchise, giving Black Ops 6‚Äôs character movement both weight and smoothness that‚Äôs satisfying to any gamer. The guns hit hard with the recoil animations, reload animations, and gunfire sounds. Call of Duty has perfected War as Entertainment and the reason why people will keep coming back for more. 

But all the shiny veneer is immediately revealed as the epitome of mediocrity with Black Op 6‚Äôs campaign. Despite some incredible missions with top notch game design, Black Op 6‚Äôs narrative fails to deliver on nearly every level. The opening mission, set in Kuwait during the Gulf War, boasts beautiful visuals but a poor player experience. It‚Äôs a boring mission, employing all the usual CoD cliches to apathetic effect. But the next mission, set in the fictional city state of Avalon, is a very good mission with game design that allows for player freedom to approach the level with combat or stealth. This is the status quo for the campaign. For every high quality mission, it will be followed by mediocrity and desperation and this continues until the very end. 

The game‚Äôs best mission, High Rollers, shows us what this game could have been if they committed to a singular vision. It‚Äôs almost innovative, highly entertaining, and develops character rapport for its cast. It‚Äôs Ocean‚Äôs Eleven but with CIA agents, a great combination.

The mission, Emergence, is a particular highlight of this game‚Äôs poor quality, employing outlandish plot elements and poorly designed gameplay to throw off the player from the typical CoD routine. It reads as a rip-off of better games such as Control and it hurts the experience. Perhaps YOU ARE better off playing Control. You only have one life after all.

The campaign is also, somehow, allergic to tackling political themes despite being a game about the Gulf War, internal CIA politics, and espionage. It is not interested in analyzing America‚Äôs role in armed conflict or the consequences of American Interventionism through agencies like the CIA. Instead, you get a run of the mill spy story about an evil organization and reinforce America‚Äôs position as the top dog of the world. It‚Äôs America, World Police nonsense that should have been thrown out years ago.
Let this be my indictment against the entire franchise after 2012. Black Ops 6 is everything Call of Duty has become. American Imperialist propaganda designed to reinforce America‚Äôs ‚Äúintegrity‚Äù in mainstream culture while indulging in its insecurities as Earth‚Äôs leading nation. It will say that ‚Äúthere is always an enemy‚Äù in an attempt to justify the endless perpetuation of War and State Violence by America. The real horror of Call of Duty is how it normalizes this rhetoric. War, killing, torture, and the destruction of human rights is ‚Äúokay‚Äù as long as its for Mother America. Call of Duty Black Ops 6 feels like its written by unquestioning ghouls, resulting in no human qualities in the narrative whatsoever. What remains is the husk of War masquerading as addictive entertainment. In a fair world, $400 million dollars would not be spent on these games.

Remember, there are better and more fulfilling games to play.

4/10.

(Review because of Singleplayer only)

It's... bad...
Haven't played any CoD in a while. Multiplayer was great in CoD MW2 and even though they let cheaters back in the game after the release of MW3, but it was still fun. Oh... right... I'm talking about old MW2 from 2009 of course. Don't play Multiplayer nowadays, but the campaign was quite good back then too and I like a good shooter campaign. Battlefield 4, the old Modern Warfare trilogy or Titanfall 2? Great campaigns. And now BO6 is even free to play for a few days, so I can finally play a few hours worth of campaign without paying at least 20 bucks, which still is the usual 50% off "deal" even for older CoD games.

Well... as you can see, I've played the CoD:BO6 campaign for a little over an hour. I expected nothing much. Just some over the top epic action mixed with a basic story. Similar plain old fun, like the old Modern Warfare Trilogy did it.

Why didn't I play more? Well.. I expected over the top action and got woke bullsh!t. I usually don't care about the characters of a game, but I still hate "inclusion overload", where it's obvious that they cared more for the number of "inclusive characters" than anything else. Boss-Lady, wheel-chair dude, guy with huge-a** nerd glasses right at the beginning and then another boss-lady with short hair in the second mission. But of course, she's actually really cool, since there's playing loud cool music in the van when we meet her...

In moderation it would be ok. Heck, if the story would be extremely engaging from the get-go and therefore kinda distract from them, then I probably wouldn't even mind those characters. But the slow and non-engaging beginning pretty much directs your attention on the characters. Pair this with a statistically very unlikely combination of characters, which reach pretty much "in your face" levels of "inclusion for inclusions sake" and the only thing I'm saying is: "Thanks, I hate it!"

I‚Äôve been gaming since the ‚Äò90s. But I haven‚Äôt seen this kind of sh.it from a game in a long time ‚Äî battle passes, microtransactions, and buggy bans.

[h3][b]BO6[/b] Campaign[/h3]

A cliche betrayal story with usual CoD gameplay. 

All aside, Case (the character we played most) does not even have a face or voice.

This'll be long, but CoD HQ is by far the most frustrating program I've ever used, not to mention that you need to download 100GB+ just for the campaign to load forever until crashing (and the constant re-download of 'shader optimization'), I know that shop/bundles take up most of the space which is a ridiculous amount of a game size WITHOUT DLCs (campaign/multiplayer/zombies/special-ops)

Despite making MWII and MWIII as separated games to download, you still need to re-download them, from which MWII takes up 25GB without DLCs, MW2019 takes up 80GB without DLCs. Not even gonna start with the pricing on these 'reboot' games, OG CoD games don't get sales higher than 45% off either, might as well just go spend your cash on the latest games like HK: Silksong, BF6, Silent Hill F, and Little Nightmare 3 - they offer more content for their pricing. Devs don't need to create a game yearly, no one is forcing them to!

I miss the good ol' CoD where I didn't need WI-FI just to play the campaigns, had a physical copy of game instead of digital one, no cheaters in multiplayer lobbies, zombies felt more exciting to play, and I didn't have to worry if my PC will run the game or nah (not everyone can afford a good PC nowadays).

But, I must say that I enjoyed the character interactions in MWII campaign, actors did a great job.

üéÆ Call of Duty: Black Ops 6 ‚Äì A Review by a Totally Not-Addicted Gamer üéÆ

If you‚Äôve ever wanted to feel like a 90s action movie star, a Cold War spy, and a zombie-slaying maniac‚Äîall while yelling at 12-year-olds who somehow have better aim than you‚Äîthen Call of Duty: Black Ops 6 is your new digital home.

üïµÔ∏è‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Campaign: Mission: Implausible The campaign is a glorious mashup of Mission: Impossible, Jason Bourne, and Scooby-Doo if Scooby carried an M4 and had a vendetta against bioweapons. You‚Äôll sneak into political galas, rob casinos, and even rub shoulders with Bill Clinton (yes, really). It‚Äôs like someone let a Red Bull-fueled screenwriter loose in a history museum and said, ‚ÄúMake it explode‚Äù.

üéØ Multiplayer: John Woo Meets Gym Class Multiplayer is where this game flexes its muscles‚Äîliterally. The new ‚Äúomni-movement‚Äù system lets you slide, dive, wall-hop, and probably do your taxes mid-air if you‚Äôre skilled enough. Every match feels like a deleted scene from Hard-Boiled, minus the doves (but give it time).

üßü‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Zombies: The Undead Are Back, Baby Zombies mode is back and cheesier than a 90s pizza commercial. You‚Äôll fight off waves of the undead while solving puzzles, unlocking safehouses, and wondering why the guy in the hazmat suit is doing Dark Souls dodge rolls while throwing Joker gas. It‚Äôs absurd, it‚Äôs campy, and it‚Äôs glorious.

üí• Final Verdict: Black Ops 6 is like a triple-shot espresso with a side of C4. It‚Äôs not perfect‚Äîsome campaign moments feel like they were written by a committee of confused time travelers‚Äîbut it‚Äôs the most fun I‚Äôve had yelling ‚ÄúTango down!‚Äù since I accidentally scared my cat with a Nerf gun.

‚≠ê 8.5/10 ‚Äì Would definitely recommend, especially if you enjoy high-octane chaos, nostalgic espionage, and the sweet, sweet sound of a perfectly timed headshot.

Now if you‚Äôll excuse me, I have to go back to arguing with a 13-year-old about who really carried the last match. Spoiler: it was me. Probably.

Gameplay Fatigue
Omnimovement 2.0 promised fluidity, but wall-jumping and multi-directional slides feel gimmicky rather than game-changing. The movement perks system adds complexity without meaningful payoff.

Overclocking gear sounds cool on paper, but in practice, it creates imbalance. Players who master the system dominate, while casuals get steamrolled.

Storyline Confusion
Set in 2035, the campaign tries to be cerebral, with psychological warfare and fear-based manipulation. But the narrative is bloated and hard to follow, especially for those not steeped in Black Ops lore.

David Mason returns, but his arc feels recycled. The emotional stakes are low, and the villain‚Äôs ‚Äúweaponized fear‚Äù concept is underdeveloped.

Zombies Mode: Stale Brains
The new ‚ÄúAshes of the Damned‚Äù map introduces a Wonder Vehicle, but it‚Äôs more novelty than necessity. The round-based format feels dated, and the undead AI lacks challenge.

Despite returning characters, the mode doesn‚Äôt evolve meaningfully. It‚Äôs nostalgic, but not fresh.

Multiplayer Misfires
Treyarch removed skill-based matchmaking (SBMM), which sounds great for veterans‚Äîbut it‚Äôs chaos for newcomers. Lobbies are now wildly unbalanced.

Persistent lobbies are back, but they often devolve into spawn-trap nightmares. The new maps are visually striking but suffer from poor pacing and choke points.

Monetization & Cosmetics
Vault Edition skins and in-game purchases are everywhere. While Treyarch promised fewer ‚Äústupid character skins,‚Äù the cosmetic overload still feels like a cash grab.

Verdict: A Missed Opportunity
Black Ops 7 tries to please everyone and ends up pleasing few. It‚Äôs a Frankenstein of past mechanics, experimental ideas, and corporate polish‚Äîbut it lacks soul. If you‚Äôre nostalgic for the glory days of Black Ops 2, this won‚Äôt scratch the itch. If you‚Äôre new to the franchise, it‚Äôs a rough onboarding.

Updates are nowhere NEAR the phrase "few and far between". It feels like every weekend there's a new season with an update to match. FIFTY GIGS worth?!?!? And what's changed??? Nothing! It fills my storage, it lags like a powerpoint presentation, installation is more of a hassle than installing 200 mods for Skyrim. I download 150GB from Steam. I open the game and Voila - ANOTHER 40GB DOWNLOAD!

Honestly, if the size is because of the graphics, have them as a free DLC! People can choose to download it and people can choose not to. Not everyone has the 5090 and not everyone has a dang 50PB drive for ts.

But as it stands, this game is TOO demanding and TOO much of a hassle. I installed it to play with my friend, but after needing to update multiple times tens of GBs within the same month (I live in a shithole, mind you), it's sucking up my bandwidth and storage when I could replace it with multiple other games that are actually worth a damn.

The modern Call of Duty experience is a behemoth, offering high-octane action across cinematic Campaigns, competitive Multiplayer, and the expansive free-to-play Warzone. What I like most is the series' signature, ultra-tight gunplay, which is unmatched in the FPS genre, coupled with the new Omni-movement introduced in Black Ops 6. This heightened mobility brings a thrilling, almost acrobatic layer to the core movement, making combat incredibly engaging whether you're playing 6v6 or diving across a map in Warzone.

However, the major downside remains the aggressive monetization and integration system. The sheer volume of cosmetic bundles and the sometimes overwhelming pressure to maintain the seasonal grind can distract from the excellent gameplay. Furthermore, the massive size of the entire install can be a barrier for many players.

Edit: I forgot to mention, you will not get Call of Duty Black Ops 6 directly added to your Steam Library with the Blue New-Labelled Tag. To access your BO6 game, search of Call of Duty Launcher on your Steam Library and go to its DLC section and you can install the game from there! Yes, you don't own the game in the first hand since everything, even the campaign is tied to the Activision servers, so better play this game along with the newer COD titles on PC Game Pass and avoid buying them even at a discounted price, unless Activision decides to make the campaign part totally accessible offline, and it shows as a separate entry or game on our Steam Library with all our playtime and achievements. Thank you.
